eu.davidea.flexibleadapter

Class FlexibleAdapter<T extends IFlexible>

  • java.lang.Object
    • androidx.recyclerview.widget.RecyclerView.Adapter
      • eu.davidea.flexibleadapter.SelectableAdapter
        • eu.davidea.flexibleadapter.AnimatorAdapter
          • eu.davidea.flexibleadapter.FlexibleAdapter<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    FastScroller.AdapterInterface, FastScroller.BubbleTextCreator, FastScroller.OnScrollStateChangeListener, ItemTouchHelperCallback.AdapterCallback

    public class FlexibleAdapter<T extends IFlexible>
extends AnimatorAdapter
implements ItemTouchHelperCallback.AdapterCallback
    This Adapter is backed by an ArrayList of arbitrary objects of class T, where T is your adapter object containing the data of a single item. This Adapter simplifies the development by providing a set of standard methods to handle changes on the data set such as: selecting, filtering, adding, removing, moving and animating an item.

    With version 5.0.0, T item must implement IFlexible item interface as base item for all view types and new methods have been added in order to:

    • handle Headers/Sections with IHeader and ISectionable items;
    • expand and collapse IExpandable items;
    • drag&drop and swipe any items.
    Since:
    03/05/2015 Created
    16/01/2016 Expandable items
    24/01/2016 Drag&Drop, Swipe-to-dismiss
    30/01/2016 Class now extends AnimatorAdapter that extends SelectableAdapter
    02/02/2016 New code reorganization, new item interfaces and full refactoring
    08/02/2016 Headers/Sections
    10/02/2016 The class is not abstract anymore, it is ready to be used
    20/02/2016 Sticky headers
    22/04/2016 Endless Scrolling
    13/07/2016 Update and Filter operations are executed asynchronously (high performance on big list)
    25/11/2016 Scrollable Headers and Footers; Reviewed EndlessScroll
    28/03/2017 Adapter now makes a copy of the provided list at startup, updateDataSet and filterItems
    10/04/2017 Endless Top Scrolling
    15/04/2017 Starting or resetting the Filter will empty the bin of the deletedItems
    23/04/2017 Wrapper class for any third type of LayoutManagers
    04/02/2018 Child view click
    13/02/2018 Multi filter
    See Also:
    AnimatorAdapter, SelectableAdapter, IFlexible, FlexibleViewHolder, ExpandableViewHolder

      • FlexibleAdapter

        public FlexibleAdapter(@Nullable
                       java.util.List<T> items)
        Simple Constructor with NO listeners!
        Parameters:
        items - items to display.
        Since:
        4.2.0 Created
        5.0.0-rc2 Copy of the Original List is done internally
        See Also:
        FlexibleAdapter(List, Object), FlexibleAdapter(List, Object, boolean)

      • FlexibleAdapter

        public FlexibleAdapter(@Nullable
                       java.util.List<T> items,
                       @Nullable
                       java.lang.Object listeners)
        Main Constructor with all managed listeners for ViewHolder and the Adapter itself.

        The listener must be a single instance of a class, usually Activity or Fragment, where you can implement how to handle the different events.

        THE ADAPTER WORKS WITH A COPY OF THE ORIGINAL LIST: new ArrayList<T>(originalList);

        Parameters:
        items - items to display
        listeners - can be an instance of:
        • FlexibleAdapter.OnItemClickListener
        • FlexibleAdapter.OnItemLongClickListener
        • FlexibleAdapter.OnItemMoveListener
        • FlexibleAdapter.OnItemSwipeListener
        • FlexibleAdapter.OnStickyHeaderChangeListener
        • FlexibleAdapter.OnUpdateListener
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1 Created
        5.0.0-rc2 Copy of the Original List is done internally
        See Also:
        FlexibleAdapter(List), FlexibleAdapter(List, Object, boolean), addListener(Object)

      • FlexibleAdapter

        public FlexibleAdapter(@Nullable
                       java.util.List<T> items,
                       @Nullable
                       java.lang.Object listeners,
                       boolean stableIds)
        Same as FlexibleAdapter(List, Object) with possibility to set stableIds.

        Tip: Setting true allows the RecyclerView to rebind only items really changed after a refresh with RecyclerView.Adapter.notifyDataSetChanged() or after swapping Adapter. This increases performance.
        Set true only if items implement Object.hashCode() and have unique ids. The method RecyclerView.Adapter.setHasStableIds(boolean) will be called.

        Parameters:
        stableIds - set true if item implements hashcode() and have unique ids.
        Since:
        5.0.0-b8 Created
        5.0.0-rc2 Copy of the Original List is done internally
        See Also:
        FlexibleAdapter(List), FlexibleAdapter(List, Object), addListener(Object)

        This method is automatically called from the Constructor.

        Parameters:

        this Adapter, so the call can be chained

        5.0.0-b6
        See Also:

      • removeListener

        @CallSuper
public FlexibleAdapter<T> removeListener(java.lang.Object listener)
        Removes one listener from this Adapter.

        Warning:

        • In case of Click and LongClick events, it will remove also the callback from all bound ViewHolders too. To restore these 2 events on the current bound ViewHolders, call addListener(Object) providing the instance of the desired listener.
        • To remove a specific listener you have to provide the either the instance or the Class type of the listener, example: 
               removeListener(mUpdateListener);
     removeListener(FlexibleAdapter.OnItemLongClickListener.class);

        Parameters:
        listener - the listener instance or Class type to remove from this Adapter and/or from all bound ViewHolders
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc3
        See Also:
        addListener(Object)

      • toggleSelection

        public void toggleSelection(int position)
        Toggles the selection status of the item at a given position.

        The behaviour depends on the selection mode previously set with SelectableAdapter.setMode(int).

        The Activated State of the ItemView is automatically set in FlexibleViewHolder.toggleActivation() called in onClick event

        Usage:

        • If you don't want any item to be selected/activated at all, just don't call this method.
        • To have actually the item visually selected you need to add a custom Selector Drawable to the background of the View, via DrawableUtils or via layout's item: android:background="?attr/selectableItemBackground", pointing to a custom Drawable in the style.xml (note: prefix ?android:attr doesn't work).

        Overrides:
        toggleSelection in class SelectableAdapter
        Parameters:
        position - position of the item to toggle the selection status for.
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1

      • selectAll

        public void selectAll(java.lang.Integer... viewTypes)
        Helper to automatically select all the items of the viewType equal to the viewType of the first selected item.

        Examples:

        • if user initially selects an expandable of type A, then only expandable items of type A can be selected.
        • if user initially selects a non-expandable of type B, then only items of type B can be selected.
        • The developer can override this behaviour by passing a list of viewTypes for which he wants to force the selection.

        Overrides:
        selectAll in class SelectableAdapter
        Parameters:
        viewTypes - All the desired viewTypes to be selected, providing no view types, will automatically select all the viewTypes of the first item user has selected
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1

      • clearSelection

        @CallSuper
public void clearSelection()
        Clears the selection status for all items one by one and it doesn't stop animations in the items.

        Note 1: Items are not rebound, so an eventual animation is not stopped!
        Note 2: This method use java.util.Iterator on synchronized collection to avoid java.util.ConcurrentModificationException.

        Overrides:
        clearSelection in class SelectableAdapter
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1

      • updateDataSet

        @CallSuper
public void updateDataSet(@Nullable
                                      java.util.List<T> items)
        Convenience method of updateDataSet(List, boolean) (You should read the comments of this method).

        Parameters:

        5.0.0-rc2 Copy of the Original List done internally
        See Also:

      • updateDataSet

        @CallSuper
public void updateDataSet(@Nullable
                                      java.util.List<T> items,
                                      boolean animate)
        This method will refresh the entire data set content. Optionally, all changes can be animated, limited by the value previously set with setAnimateToLimit(int) to improve performance on very big list. Should provide animate=false to directly invoke RecyclerView.Adapter.notifyDataSetChanged() without any animations, if stableIds is not set!

        Note:

        • Scrollable Headers and Footers (if existent) will be restored in this call.
        • I strongly recommend to implement Object.hashCode() to all adapter items along with Object.equals(Object): This Adapter is making use of HashSet to improve performance.

        Note: The following methods will be also called at the end of the operation:
        1. expandItemsAtStartUp()
        2. showAllHeaders() if headers are shown
        3. onPostUpdate()
        4. FlexibleAdapter.OnUpdateListener.onUpdateEmptyView(int) if the listener is set
        Parameters:
        items - the new data set
        animate - true to animate the changes, false for an instant refresh
        Since:
        5.0.0-b7 Created
        5.0.0-rc2 Copy of the Original List done internally
        See Also:
        updateDataSet(List), setAnimateToLimit(int), onPostUpdate()

      • getItemCount

        public int getItemCount()
        Returns the total number of items in the data set held by the adapter (headers and footers INCLUDED). Use getMainItemCount() with false as parameter to retrieve only real items excluding headers and footers.

        Note: This method cannot be overridden since the selection and the internal methods rely on it.

        Specified by:
        getItemCount in class androidx.recyclerview.widget.RecyclerView.Adapter
        Returns:
        the total number of items (headers and footers INCLUDED) held by the adapter
        Since:
        1.0.0
        See Also:
        getMainItemCount(), getItemCountOfTypes(Integer...), isEmpty()

      • getMainItemCount

        public final int getMainItemCount()
        Returns the total number of items in the data set held by the adapter.
        • Provide true (default behavior) to count all items, same result of getItemCount().
        • Provide false to count only main items (headers and footers are EXCLUDED).
        Note: This method cannot be overridden since internal methods rely on it.
        Returns:
        the total number of items held by the adapter, with or without headers and footers, depending by the provided parameter
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc1
        See Also:
        getItemCount(), getItemCountOfTypes(Integer...)

        getItemCount(), getItemCountOfTypes(Integer...)

      • getGlobalPositionOf

        public final int getGlobalPositionOf(IFlexible item)
        Retrieves the global position of the item in the Adapter list. If no scrollable Headers are added, the global position coincides with the cardinal position.

        This method cannot be overridden since the entire library relies on it.

        Parameters:
        item - the item for which the position needs to be found
        Returns:
        the global position in the Adapter if found, -1 otherwise
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        getSameTypePositionOf(IFlexible)

      • getCardinalPositionOf

        public final int getCardinalPositionOf(@NonNull
                                       IFlexible item)
        Retrieves the position of the Main item in the Adapter list excluding the scrollable Headers. If no scrollable Headers are added, the cardinal position coincides with the global position.

        Note:
        - This method is NOT suitable to call when managing items: ALL insert, remove, move and swap operations, should done with global position getGlobalPositionOf(IFlexible).
        - This method cannot be overridden.

        Parameters:
        item - the item for which the position needs to be found
        Returns:
        the position in the Adapter excluding the Scrollable Headers, -1 otherwise
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc1
        See Also:
        getSameTypePositionOf(IFlexible)

      • getSameTypePositionOf

        public final int getSameTypePositionOf(@NonNull
                                       IFlexible item)
        Retrieves the position of any item in the Adapter counting only the items of the same view type of the provided item and excluding all the others view types.

        Tip: You can identify the number of the section (you need to add +1) of any headers OR to retrieve the position of an item as it were the only view type visible in the Adapter.

        Parameters:
        item - the item for which the position needs to be found
        Returns:
        the position in the Adapter counting only the items of the same type, -1 otherwise
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc3
        See Also:
        getSubPositionOf(IFlexible)

      • calculatePositionFor

        public int calculatePositionFor(@NonNull
                                java.lang.Object item,
                                @Nullable
                                java.util.Comparator<IFlexible> comparator)
        New method to extract the new position where the item should lay.

        Note: The Comparator object should be customized to support all types of items this Adapter is managing or a ClassCastException will be raised.

        If the Comparator is null the returned position is 0 (first position).
        Parameters:
        item - the item to evaluate the insertion
        comparator - the Comparator object with the logic to sort the list
        Returns:
        the position resulted from sorting with the provided Comparator
        Since:
        5.0.0-b7

      • addScrollableHeader

        public final boolean addScrollableHeader(@NonNull
                                         T headerItem)
        Adds a Scrollable Header.

        Scrollable Headers have the following characteristic:

        • lay always before any main item.
        • cannot be selectable nor draggable.
        • cannot be inserted twice, but many can be inserted.
        • any new header will be inserted before the existent.
        • can be of any type so they can be bound at runtime with any data inside.
        • won't be filtered because they won't be part of the main list, but added separately at the initialization phase
        • can be added and removed with certain delay.

        Parameters:
        headerItem - the header item to be added
        Returns:
        true if the header has been successfully added, false if the header already exists
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc1
        See Also:
        getScrollableHeaders(), addScrollableHeaderWithDelay(IFlexible, long, boolean)

      • addScrollableFooter

        public final boolean addScrollableFooter(@NonNull
                                         T footerItem)
        Adds a Scrollable Footer.

        Scrollable Footers have the following characteristic:

        • lay always after any main item.
        • cannot be selectable nor draggable.
        • cannot be inserted twice, but many can be inserted.
        • cannot scroll animate, when inserted for the first time.
        • any new footer will be inserted after the existent.
        • can be of any type so they can be bound at runtime with any data inside.
        • won't be filtered because they won't be part of the main list, but added separately at the initialization phase
        • can be added and removed with certain delay.
        • endless progressItem is handled as a Scrollable Footer, but it will be always displayed between the main items and the others footers.

        Parameters:
        footerItem - the footer item to be added
        Returns:
        true if the footer has been successfully added, false if the footer already exists
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc1
        See Also:
        getScrollableFooters(), addScrollableFooterWithDelay(IFlexible, long, boolean)

      • removeScrollableHeader

      • setStickyHeaders

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setStickyHeaders(boolean sticky)
        Enables/Disables the sticky header feature with default sticky layout container.

        Note:

        • You should consider to display headers with setDisplayHeadersAtStartUp(boolean): Feature can enabled/disabled freely, but if headers are hidden nothing will happen.
        • Only in case of "Sticky Header" items you must provide true to the constructor: FlexibleViewHolder.FlexibleViewHolder(View, FlexibleAdapter, boolean).
        • Optionally, you can set a custom sticky layout container that must be already inflated.
          Check setStickyHeaders(boolean, ViewGroup).
        • Optionally, you can set a layout elevation: Header item elevation is used first, if not set, default elevation of 21f pixel is used.
        • Sticky headers are clickable as any views, but cannot be dragged nor swiped.
        • Content and linkage are automatically updated.
        • Sticky layout container is fade-in and fade-out animated when feature is respectively enabled and disabled.
        • Sticky container can be elevated only if the header item layout has elevation (Do not exaggerate with elevation).

        Important! In order to display the Refresh circle AND the FastScroller on the Top of the sticky container, the RecyclerView must be wrapped with a FrameLayout as following: 
         <FrameLayout
     android:layout_width="match_parent"
     android:layout_height="match_parent">

     <android.support.v7.widget.RecyclerView
         android:id="@+id/recycler_view"
         android:layout_width="match_parent"
         android:layout_height="match_parent"/>

 </FrameLayout>
        Parameters:
        sticky - true to initialize sticky headers with default container, false to disable them
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if this Adapter was not attached to the RecyclerView
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc1
        See Also:
        setStickyHeaders(boolean, ViewGroup), setDisplayHeadersAtStartUp(boolean), setStickyHeaderElevation(int)

      • setStickyHeaders

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setStickyHeaders(boolean sticky,
                                           @Nullable
                                           android.view.ViewGroup stickyContainer)
        Enables/Disables the sticky header feature with a custom sticky layout container.

        Important: Read the javaDoc of the overloaded method setStickyHeaders(boolean).

        Parameters:
        sticky - true to initialize sticky headers, false to disable them
        stickyContainer - user defined and already inflated sticky layout that will hold the sticky header itemViews
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if this Adapter was not attached to the RecyclerView
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc1
        See Also:
        setStickyHeaders(boolean), setDisplayHeadersAtStartUp(boolean), setStickyHeaderElevation(int)

      • setDisplayHeadersAtStartUp

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setDisplayHeadersAtStartUp(boolean displayHeaders)
        Sets if all headers should be shown at startup by the Adapter automatically.

        If called, this method won't trigger notifyItemInserted() and scrolling animations are instead performed if the header item was configured with animation: Headers will be loaded/bound along with others items.

        Note: Headers can only be shown or hidden all together.

        Default value is false (headers are not shown at startup).

        Parameters:
        displayHeaders - true to display headers, false to keep them hidden
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b6
        See Also:
        showAllHeaders(), AnimatorAdapter.setAnimationOnForwardScrolling(boolean)

      • setHeadersShown

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setHeadersShown(boolean headersShown)
        Manually change the flag to indicate that headers are inserted(or not) in the main list by the user and the Adapter doesn't(does) have to automatically insert them.

        Default value is false (headers are not shown at startup).

        Parameters:
        headersShown - true, if headers are already shown
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0

      • showAllHeaders

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> showAllHeaders()
        Shows all headers in the RecyclerView at their linked position.

        If called at startup, this method will trigger notifyItemInserted for a different loading effect: Headers will be inserted after the items!

        Note: Headers can only be shown or hidden all together.
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        hideAllHeaders(), setDisplayHeadersAtStartUp(boolean)

      • linkHeaderTo

        private void linkHeaderTo(T item,
                          IHeader header,
                          @Nullable
                          java.lang.Object payload)
        Internal method to link the header to the new item.

        Used by the Adapter during the Remove/Restore/Move operations.

        The new item looses the previous header, and if the old header is not shared, old header is added to the orphan list.
        Parameters:
        item - the item that holds the header
        header - the header item
        payload - any non-null user object to notify the header and the item (the payload will be therefore passed to the bind method of the items ViewHolder), pass null to not notify the header and item
        Since:
        5.0.0-b6

      • unlinkHeaderFrom

                              @Nullable
                              java.lang.Object payload)

        Used by the Adapter during the Remove/Restore/Move operations.

      • setEndlessPageSize

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setEndlessPageSize(int endlessPageSize)
        Sets the limit to automatically disable the endless feature when coming items size is less than the page size.

        When endless feature is disabled a RecyclerView.Adapter.notifyItemChanged(int, Object) with payload Payload.NO_MORE_LOAD will be triggered on the progressItem, so you can display a message or change the views in this item.

        Default value is 0 (limit is ignored).
        Parameters:
        endlessPageSize - the size limit for each page
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc1

        The current setting for the endless target item count limit.

        Tip: This limit is ignored if value is 0.

        Returns:
        the target items count limit, if the limit is not set, 0 is returned.
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc1
        See Also:
        setEndlessTargetCount(int)

      • setEndlessTargetCount

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setEndlessTargetCount(int endlessTargetCount)
        Sets the limit to automatically disable the endless feature when the total items count in the Adapter is equals or bigger than the target count.

        When endless feature is disabled a RecyclerView.Adapter.notifyItemChanged(int, Object) with payload Payload.NO_MORE_LOAD will be triggered on the progressItem, so you can display a message or change the views in this item.

        Default value is 0 (limit is ignored).
        Parameters:
        endlessTargetCount - the total items count limit
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc1
        See Also:
        getEndlessTargetCount()

      • setLoadingMoreAtStartUp

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setLoadingMoreAtStartUp(boolean enable)
        Sets if Endless / Loading More should be triggered at start-up, especially when the list is empty.

        Default value is false.

        Parameters:
        enable - true to trigger a loading at start up, false to trigger loading with binding
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained

      • setEndlessProgressItem

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setEndlessProgressItem(@Nullable
                                                 T progressItem)
        Sets the progressItem to be displayed at the end of the list and activate the Loading More feature.

        Using this method, the FlexibleAdapter.EndlessScrollListener won't be called so that you can handle a click event to load more items upon a user request.

        To correctly implement "Load more upon a user request" check the Wiki page of this library.
        Parameters:
        progressItem - the item representing the progress bar
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b8
        See Also:
        isEndlessScrollEnabled(), setEndlessScrollListener(EndlessScrollListener, IFlexible)

      • setEndlessScrollListener

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setEndlessScrollListener(@Nullable
                                                   FlexibleAdapter.EndlessScrollListener endlessScrollListener,
                                                   @NonNull
                                                   T progressItem)
        Sets the progressItem to be displayed at the end of the list and Sets the callback to automatically load more items asynchronously(your duty) (no further user action is needed but the scroll).
        Parameters:
        endlessScrollListener - the callback to invoke the asynchronous loading
        progressItem - the item representing the progress bar
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b6
        See Also:
        isEndlessScrollEnabled(), setEndlessProgressItem(IFlexible)

      • setEndlessScrollThreshold

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setEndlessScrollThreshold(int thresholdItems)
        Sets the minimum number of items still to bind to start the automatic loading.

        Default value is 1.

        Parameters:
        thresholdItems - minimum number of unbound items to start loading more items
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b6

      • onLoadMore

        protected void onLoadMore(int position)
        This method is called automatically when an item is bound.
        Parameters:
        position - the current binding position
        Since:
        5.0.0-b6
        5.0.0-rc1 Added limits check and progressItem with Scrollable Footers

      • onLoadMoreComplete

        public void onLoadMoreComplete(@Nullable
                               java.util.List<T> newItems)
        To call when more items are successfully loaded.

        When noMoreLoad OR onError OR onCancel, pass empty list or null to hide the progressItem.

        In this case the ProgressItem is removed immediately.
        Parameters:
        newItems - the list of the new items, can be empty or null
        Since:
        5.0.0-b6

      • onLoadMoreComplete

        public void onLoadMoreComplete(@Nullable
                               java.util.List<T> newItems,
                               long delay)
        Call this method to complete the action of the Loading more items.

        When noMoreLoad OR onError OR onCancel, pass empty list or null to hide the progressItem. When limits are set, endless feature will be disabled. To enable again call setEndlessProgressItem(IFlexible).

        Optionally you can pass a delay time to still display the item with the latest information inside. The message has to be handled inside the bindViewHolder of the item.

        A RecyclerView.Adapter.notifyItemChanged(int, Object) with payload Payload.NO_MORE_LOAD will be triggered on the progressItem, so you can display a message or change the views in this item.

        Parameters:
        newItems - the list of the new items, can be empty or null
        delay - the delay used to remove the progress item or -1 to disable the loading forever and to keep the progress item visible.
        Since:
        5.0.0-b8
        5.0.0-rc1 Added limits check and changed progressItem to Scrollable Footer
        5.0.0-rc2 Added Top Endless

      • showProgressItem

        private void showProgressItem()
        Called at each loading more.

      • hideProgressItem

        private void hideProgressItem()
        Called when loading more should continue.

      • noMoreLoad

        private void noMoreLoad(int newItemsSize)
        Called when no more items are loaded.

      • isAutoCollapseOnExpand

        public boolean isAutoCollapseOnExpand()
        Returns:
        true if collapseOnExpand is enabled, false otherwise
        Since:
        5.0.0-b8

      • setAutoCollapseOnExpand

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setAutoCollapseOnExpand(boolean collapseOnExpand)
        Automatically collapse all previous expanded parents before expand the new clicked parent.

        Default value is false (disabled).

        Tip: This parameter works in collaboration with setMinCollapsibleLevel(int).
        Parameters:
        collapseOnExpand - true to collapse others items, false to just expand the current
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        setMinCollapsibleLevel(int)

      • isRecursiveCollapse

        public boolean isRecursiveCollapse()
        Returns:
        true if collapseSubLevels is enabled, false otherwise
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc3

      • setRecursiveCollapse

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setRecursiveCollapse(boolean collapseSubLevels)
        Automatically collapse all inner sub expandable when higher parent is collapsed.
        By keeping this parameter false, their expanded status remains expanded=true so when the higher parent is expanded again, the sub expandables will appear again expanded.

        Default value is false (keep expanded status).

        Tip: This parameter works in collaboration with setMinCollapsibleLevel(int).
        Parameters:
        collapseSubLevels - true to allow inner sub expandable to collapse, false to keep the expanded status
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc3
        See Also:
        setMinCollapsibleLevel(int)

      • isAutoScrollOnExpand

        Returns:
        true if scrollOnExpand is enabled, false otherwise
        Since:
        5.0.0-b8

      • setAutoScrollOnExpand

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setAutoScrollOnExpand(boolean scrollOnExpand)
        Automatically scroll the clicked expandable item to the first visible position.

        Default value is false (disabled).

        Note: This works ONLY in combination with SmoothScrollLinearLayoutManager or with SmoothScrollGridLayoutManager available in UI extension.
        Parameters:
        scrollOnExpand - true to enable automatic scroll, false to disable
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1

                  boolean notifyParent)
        Expands an item that is IExpandable type, not yet expanded and if has subItems.

        If configured, automatic smooth scroll will be performed when necessary.

      • expand

        public int expand(T item)
        Convenience method to expand a single item. Parent will be notified.

        Expands an item that is Expandable, not yet expanded, that has subItems and no child is selected.

        If configured, automatic smooth scroll will be performed.
        Parameters:
        item - the item to expand, must be an Expandable and present in the list
        Returns:
        the number of subItems expanded
        Since:
        5.0.0-b6
        See Also:
        expand(int), expand(int, boolean), expand(IFlexible, boolean), expandAll()

      • expand

        public int expand(T item,
                  boolean init)
        Convenience method to initially expand a single item. Parent won't be notified.

        Note: Must be used in combination when adding new items, those require to be initially expanded.

        WARNING!
        Expanded status is ignored if init = true: it will always attempt to expand the item: If subItems are already visible and the new item has status expanded, the subItems will appear duplicated(!) and the automatic smooth scroll will be skipped!
        Parameters:
        item - the item to expand, must be an Expandable and present in the list
        init - true to initially expand item
        Returns:
        the number of subItems expanded
        Since:
        5.0.0-b7
        See Also:
        expand(int), expand(int, boolean), expand(IFlexible), expandAll()

      • expand

        private int expand(int position,
                   boolean expandAll,
                   boolean init,
                   boolean notifyParent)
        Convenience method to initially expand a single item.

        Note: Must be used in combination with adding new items that require to be initially expanded.

        WARNING!
        Expanded status is ignored if init = true: it will always attempt to expand the item: If subItems are already visible and the new item has status expanded, the subItems will appear duplicated(!) and the automatic smooth scroll will be skipped!
        Parameters:
        position - the position of the item to expand
        init - true to initially expand item
        notifyParent - true to notify the parent with Payload.EXPANDED
        Returns:
        the number of subItems expanded
        Since:
        5.0.0-rc2

      • collapse

        public int collapse(int position)
        Collapses an IExpandable item that is already expanded and if no subItem is selected.

        Multilevel option behaviours:

        • IExpandable subItems, that are expanded, can be recursively collapsed, see setRecursiveCollapse(boolean).
        • You can set the minimum level to auto-collapse siblings, see setMinCollapsibleLevel(int).

        Parent won't be notified.
        Parameters:
        position - the position of the item to collapse
        Returns:
        the number of subItems collapsed
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        collapseAll()

      • collapse

        Returns:
        the number of subItems collapsed
        Since:

      • addItemWithDelay

        public void addItemWithDelay(int position,
                             @NonNull
                             T item,
                             long delay,
                             boolean scrollToPosition)
        Inserts the given item at desired position or Add item at last position with a delay and auto-scroll to the position.

        Scrolling animation is automatically preserved, meaning that, notification for animation is ignored.

        Useful at startup, when there's an item to add after Adapter Animations is completed.
        Parameters:
        position - position of the item to add
        item - the item to add
        delay - a non-negative delay
        scrollToPosition - true if RecyclerView should scroll after item has been added, false otherwise
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        addItem(int, IFlexible), addItems(int, List), addSubItems(int, int, IExpandable, List, boolean, Object), removeItemWithDelay(IFlexible, long, boolean)

      • addItem

        public boolean addItem(int position,
                       @NonNull
                       T item)
        Inserts the given item at the specified position or Adds the item to the end of the list (no matters if the new position is out of bounds!).
        Parameters:

        item - the item to add

      • addItems

        public boolean addItems(int position,
                        @NonNull
                        java.util.List<T> items)
        Inserts a set of items at specified position or Adds the items to the end of the list (no matters if the new position is out of bounds!).

        Note:
        - When all headers are shown, if exists, the header of this item will be shown as well, unless it's already shown, so it won't be shown twice.
        - Items will be always added between any scrollable header and footers.

        Parameters:
        position - position inside the list, if negative, items will be added to the end
        items - the set of items to add
        Returns:
        true if the internal list was successfully modified, false otherwise
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        addItem(IFlexible), addItem(int, IFlexible), addSubItems(int, int, IExpandable, List, boolean, Object)

      • addSubItem

        public boolean addSubItem(int parentPosition,
                          int subPosition,
                          @NonNull
                          T item,
                          boolean expandParent,
                          @Nullable
                          java.lang.Object payload)
        Convenience method of addSubItems(int, int, IExpandable, List, boolean, Object).
        Optionally you can pass any payload to notify the parent about the change and optimize the view binding.
        Parameters:
        parentPosition - position of the expandable item that shall contain the subItem
        subPosition - the position of the subItem in the expandable list
        item - the subItem to add in the expandable list
        expandParent - true to initially expand the parent (if needed) and after to add the subItem, false to simply add the subItem to the parent
        payload - any non-null user object to notify the parent (the payload will be therefore passed to the bind method of the parent ViewHolder), pass null to not notify the parent
        Returns:
        true if the internal list was successfully modified, false otherwise
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        addSubItems(int, int, IExpandable, List, boolean, Object)

      • addSubItems

        private boolean addSubItems(int parentPosition,
                            int subPosition,
                            @NonNull
                            IExpandable parent,
                            @NonNull
                            java.util.List<T> subItems,
                            boolean expandParent,
                            @Nullable
                            java.lang.Object payload)
        Adds new subItems on the specified parent item, to the internal list.

        In order to add subItems, the following condition must be satisfied:
        - The item resulting from the parent position is actually an IExpandable.

        Optionally, the parent can be expanded and subItems displayed.
        Optionally, you can pass any payload to notify the parent about the change and optimize the view binding.
        Parameters:
        parentPosition - position of the expandable item that shall contain the subItems
        subPosition - the start position in the parent where the new items shall be inserted
        parent - the expandable item which shall contain the new subItem
        subItems - the list of the subItems to add
        expandParent - true to initially expand the parent (if needed) and after to add the subItems, false to simply add the subItems to the parent
        payload - any non-null user object to notify the parent (the payload will be therefore passed to the bind method of the parent ViewHolder), pass null to not notify the parent
        Returns:
        true if the internal list was successfully modified, false otherwise
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        addItems(int, List)

      • addSection

        public int addSection(@NonNull
                      IHeader header)
        Adds and shows an empty section to the top (position = 0).
        Returns:
        the calculated position for the new item
        Since:
        5.0.0-b6
        See Also:
        addSection(IHeader, Comparator)

      • addSection

        public int addSection(@NonNull
                      IHeader header,
                      @Nullable
                      java.util.Comparator<IFlexible> comparator)
        Adds and shows an empty section. The new section is a IHeader item and the position is calculated after sorting the data set.

        - To add Sections to the top, set null the Comparator object or simply call addSection(IHeader);
        - To add Sections to the bottom or in the middle, implement a Comparator object able to support all the item types this Adapter is displaying or a ClassCastException will be raised.

        Parameters:
        header - the section header item to add
        comparator - the criteria to sort the Data Set used to extract the correct position of the new header
        Returns:
        the calculated position for the new item
        Since:
        5.0.0-b7

      • addItemToSection

        public int addItemToSection(@NonNull
                            ISectionable sectionable,
                            @Nullable
                            IHeader header,
                            @Nullable
                            java.util.Comparator<IFlexible> comparator)
        Adds a new item in a section when the relative position is unknown.

        The header can be a IExpandable type or IHeader type.

        The Comparator object must support all the item types this Adapter is displaying or a ClassCastException will be raised.
        Parameters:
        sectionable - the item to add
        header - the section receiving the new item
        comparator - the criteria to sort the sectionItems used to extract the correct position of the new item in the section
        Returns:
        the calculated final position for the new item
        Since:
        5.0.0-b6
        See Also:
        addItemToSection(ISectionable, IHeader, int)

      • removeItem

        public void removeItem(int position,
                       @Nullable
                       java.lang.Object payload)
        Removes an item from the internal list and notify the change.

        The item is retained for an eventual Undo.

        This method delegates the removal to removeRange.
        Parameters:
        position - The position of item to remove
        payload - any non-null user object to notify the parent (the payload will be therefore passed to the bind method of the parent ViewHolder), pass null to not notify the parent
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        removeItems(List, Object), removeRange(int, int, Object), removeAllSelectedItems(Object), removeItem(int)

      • removeItems

        public void removeItems(@Nullable
                        java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> selectedPositions,
                        @Nullable
                        java.lang.Object payload)
        Removes items by ranges, auto-collapse expanded items and notify the change.

        Every item is retained for an eventual Undo.

        Optionally you can pass any payload to notify the parent items about the change to optimize the view binding.

        This method delegates the removal to removeRange.

        Parameters:
        selectedPositions - list with item positions to remove
        payload - any non-null user object to notify the parent (the payload will be therefore passed to the bind method of the parent ViewHolder), pass null to not notify the parent
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        removeItem(int, Object), removeRange(int, int, Object), removeAllSelectedItems(Object), removeItems(List)

      • removeRange

        public void removeRange(int positionStart,
                        int itemCount)
        Same as removeRange(int, int, Object), but in this case the parent will not be notified about the change, if children are removed.
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        clear(), clearAllBut(Integer...), removeItem(int, Object), removeItems(List), removeItemsOfType(Integer...), removeAllSelectedItems(), removeRange(int, int, Object)

      • removeRange

        public void removeRange(int positionStart,
                        int itemCount,
                        @Nullable
                        java.lang.Object payload)
        Removes a list of consecutive items and notify the change.

        If the item, resulting from the provided position:

        - is not expandable with no parent, it is removed as usual.
        - is not expandable with a parent, it is removed only if the parent is expanded.
        - is expandable implementing IExpandable, it is removed as usual, but it will be collapsed if expanded.
        - has a IHeader item, the header will be automatically linked to the first item after the range or can remain orphan.

        Optionally you can pass any payload to notify the parent or the header about the change and optimize the view binding.

        Parameters:
        positionStart - the start position of the first item
        itemCount - how many items should be removed
        payload - any non-null user object to notify the parent (the payload will be therefore passed to the bind method of the parent ViewHolder), pass null to not notify the parent
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        clear(), clearAllBut(Integer...), removeItem(int, Object), removeItems(List, Object), removeRange(int, int), removeAllSelectedItems(Object), setPermanentDelete(boolean), setRestoreSelectionOnUndo(boolean), getDeletedItems(), getDeletedChildren(IExpandable), restoreDeletedItems(), emptyBin()

      • removeAllSelectedItems

        public void removeAllSelectedItems()
        Convenience method to remove all items that are currently selected.

        Parent will not be notified about the change if a child is removed.

        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        clear(), clearAllBut(Integer...), removeItem(int), removeItems(List), removeRange(int, int), removeItemsOfType(Integer...), removeAllSelectedItems(Object)

      • removeAllSelectedItems

        public void removeAllSelectedItems(@Nullable
                                   java.lang.Object payload)
        Convenience method to remove all items that are currently selected.

        Optionally, the parent item can be notified about the change if a child is removed, by providing any non-null payload.

        Parameters:
        payload - any non-null user object to notify the parent (the payload will be therefore passed to the bind method of the parent ViewHolder), pass null to not notify the parent
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        clear(), clearAllBut(Integer...), removeItem(int, Object), removeItems(List, Object), removeRange(int, int, Object), removeAllSelectedItems()

      • isPermanentDelete

        public boolean isPermanentDelete()
        Returns if items will be deleted immediately when deletion is requested.

        Default value is true (Undo mechanism is disabled).

        Returns:
        true if the items are deleted immediately, false if items are retained for an eventual restoration
        Since:
        5.0.0-b6

      • setPermanentDelete

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setPermanentDelete(boolean permanentDelete)
        Sets if the deleted items should be deleted immediately or if Adapter should cache them to restore them when requested by the user.

        Default value is true (Undo mechanism is disabled).

        Parameters:
        permanentDelete - true to delete items forever, false to use the cache for Undo feature
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b6

      • setFilter

        public void setFilter(@Nullable
                      java.io.Serializable filter)
        Sets the new filter entity.

        Note:

        • Filter object must implement Serializable (String does).
        • In case of free text (String), filter is automatically trimmed and lowercase.

        Tip: You can highlight filtered Text or Words using FlexibleUtils from UI extension:

        • FlexibleUtils#highlightText(TextView, String, String)
        • FlexibleUtils#highlightWords(TextView, String, String)

        Parameters:
        filter - the new filter entity for the items
        Since:
        5.0.0

      • setNotifyChangeOfUnfilteredItems

        public final FlexibleAdapter<T> setNotifyChangeOfUnfilteredItems(boolean notifyChange)
        With this setting, we can skip the check of the implemented method IFlexible.shouldNotifyChange(IFlexible).

        By setting false all items will be skipped by an update.

        Default value is true (items will always be notified of a change).
        Parameters:
        notifyChange - true to trigger RecyclerView.Adapter.notifyItemChanged(int), false to not update the items' content.
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1

      • setNotifyMoveOfFilteredItems

        public final FlexibleAdapter<T> setNotifyMoveOfFilteredItems(boolean notifyMove)
        This method performs a further step to nicely animate the moved items. When false, the items are not moved but removed, to be added at the correct position.

        The process is very slow on big list of the order of ~3-5000 items and higher, due to the calculation of the correct position for each item to be shifted. Use with caution!

        The slowness is higher when the filter is cleared out.

        Default value is false.

        Parameters:
        notifyMove - true to animate move changes after filtering or update data set, false otherwise
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b8

      • filterItems

        public void filterItems(@NonNull
                        java.util.List<T> unfilteredItems,
                        long delay)
        WATCH OUT! ADAPTER ALREADY CREATES A COPY OF THE PROVIDED LIST: due to internal mechanism, items are removed and/or added in order to animate items in the final list.

        Same as filterItems(List), but with a delay in the execution, useful to grab more characters from user before starting the search.

        Parameters:

        delay - any non-negative delay
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        setFilter(Serializable), filterItems(long), filterItems(List), onPostFilter(), setAnimateToLimit(int)

      • filterItems

        public void filterItems(@NonNull
                        java.util.List<T> unfilteredItems)
        WATCH OUT! ADAPTER ALREADY CREATES A COPY OF THE PROVIDED LIST: due to internal mechanism, items are removed and/or added in order to animate items in the final list.

        This method filters the provided list with the filter previously set with setFilter(Serializable). Filter object can be of any type.

        Important notes:
        1. The Filter is always executed in background, asynchronously. The method onPostFilter() is called after the filter task is completed.
        2. This method calls filterObject(IFlexible, Serializable) for each filterable item.
        3. Any pending deleted items are always deleted before filter is performed: FlexibleAdapter.OnDeleteCompleteListener.onDeleteConfirmed(int) (implemented in UndoHelper) is therefore invoked.
        4. Expandable items are picked up and displayed if at least a child is collected by the current filter.
        5. Filter is skipped while endless feature is active (loading).
        6. If filter is null, the provided list is the new list plus any Scrollable Headers and Footers if existent.
        7. Items are animated thanks to animateTo(List, Payload) BUT a limit of (default) items is set. Tip: Above this limit, RecyclerView.Adapter.notifyDataSetChanged() will be called to improve performance. You can change this limit by calling setAnimateToLimit(int).
        Parameters:
        unfilteredItems - the list to filter
        Since:
        4.1.0 Created
        5.0.0-b1 Expandable + Child filtering
        5.0.0-b8 Synchronization animations limit + AsyncFilter
        5.0.0-rc1 Scrollable Headers and Footers adaptation
        5.0.0-rc2 Copy of the Original List is done internally
        5.0.0-rc2 Removal of Undo in combination with Filter
        5.0.0 Use of any filter object, instead of only String
        See Also:
        setFilter(Serializable), filterItems(), filterItems(List, long), onPostFilter(), setAnimateToLimit(int)

      • filterItemsAsync

        private void filterItemsAsync(@NonNull
                              java.util.List<T> unfilteredItems)

      • isFiltering

        public boolean isFiltering()
        Returns:
        true if the filter is currently running, false otherwise.

      • filterObject

        private boolean filterObject(T item,
                             java.util.List<T> values)
        This method is a wrapper filter for expandable items.
        It performs filtering on the subItems returning true, if the any child should be in the filtered collection.

        If the provided item is not an expandable it will be filtered as usual by #filterObject(T, Serializable).

        Parameters:
        item - the object with subItems to be inspected
        Returns:
        true, if the object should be in the filteredResult, false otherwise
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1

      • filterExpandableObject

        private boolean filterExpandableObject(T item,
                                       java.util.List<T> filteredItems)

      • filterObject

        protected boolean filterObject(T item,
                               java.io.Serializable constraint)
        This method checks if the provided object is a type of IFilterable interface, if yes, performs the filter on the implemented method IFilterable.filter(Serializable).

        Note:
        - The item will be collected if the implemented method returns true.
        - IExpandable items are automatically picked up and displayed if at least a child is collected by the current filter. You DON'T NEED to implement the scan for the children: this is already done :-)
        - If you don't want to implement the IFilterable interface on each item, then you can override this method to have another filter logic!

        Parameters:
        item - the object to be inspected
        constraint - constraint, that the object has to fulfil
        Returns:
        true, if the object returns true as well, and so if it should be in the filteredResult, false otherwise
        Since:
        3.1.0 Created
        5.0.0-b1 Expandable + Child filtering

      • resetFilterFlags

        private void resetFilterFlags(java.util.List<T> items)
        Clears flags after filter is cleared out for Expandable items and sub items. Also restore headers visibility.

      • setAnimateToLimit

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setAnimateToLimit(int limit)
        Tunes the limit after the which the synchronization animations, occurred during updateDataSet and filter operations, are skipped and RecyclerView.Adapter.notifyDataSetChanged() will be called instead.

        Default value is items, number new items.

        Parameters:
        limit - the number of new items that, when reached, will skip synchronization animations
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b8

      • isAnimateChangesWithDiffUtil

        public boolean isAnimateChangesWithDiffUtil()
        Returns:
        true to calculate animation changes with DiffUtil, false to use default calculation.
        See Also:
        setAnimateChangesWithDiffUtil(boolean)

      • setAnimateChangesWithDiffUtil

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setAnimateChangesWithDiffUtil(boolean useDiffUtil)
        Whether use DiffUtil to calculate the changes between 2 lists after Update or Filter operations. If disabled, the advanced default calculation will be used instead.

        A time, to compare the 2 different approaches, is calculated and displayed in the log. To see the logs call SelectableAdapter.enableLogs(int) before creating the Adapter instance!

        Default value is false (default calculation is used).
        Parameters:
        useDiffUtil - true to switch the calculation and use DiffUtil, false to use the default calculation.
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        See Also:
        setDiffUtilCallback(DiffUtilCallback)

      • setDiffUtilCallback

        public FlexibleAdapter<T> setDiffUtilCallback(FlexibleAdapter.DiffUtilCallback diffUtilCallback)
        Sets a custom implementation of FlexibleAdapter.DiffUtilCallback for the DiffUtil.
        Parameters:
        diffUtilCallback - the custom callback that DiffUtil will call
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        See Also:
        setAnimateChangesWithDiffUtil(boolean)

      • animateDiff

                         java.util.List<T> newItems,
                         Payload payloadChange)

      • animateTo

        private void animateTo(@Nullable
                       java.util.List<T> newItems,
                       Payload payloadChange)
        Animate the synchronization between the old list and the new list.

        Used by filter and updateDataSet.

        Note: The animations are skipped in favor of RecyclerView.Adapter.notifyDataSetChanged() when the number of items reaches the limit. See setAnimateToLimit(int).

        Note: In case the animations are performed, unchanged items will be notified if notifyChangeOfUnfilteredItems is set true, a CHANGE payload will be set.

        Parameters:
        newItems - the new list containing the new items
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1 Created
        5.0.0-b8 Synchronization animation limit
        See Also:
        setNotifyChangeOfUnfilteredItems(boolean), setNotifyMoveOfFilteredItems(boolean), setAnimateToLimit(int)

        See Also:
        setLongPressDragEnabled(boolean)

      • setLongPressDragEnabled

        public final FlexibleAdapter<T> setLongPressDragEnabled(boolean longPressDragEnabled)
        Enables / Disables the drag of the item when long-press the entire itemView.

        Note: This will skip LongClick on the view in order to handle the LongPress, however the LongClick listener will be called if necessary in the new FlexibleViewHolder.onActionStateChanged(int, int).

        Requires the Adapter being attached to the RecyclerView. Default value is false.
        Parameters:
        longPressDragEnabled - true to activate, false otherwise
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1

      • isHandleDragEnabled

        public final boolean isHandleDragEnabled()
        Returns whether ItemTouchHelper should start a drag and drop operation by touching its handle.

        Default value is false.

        To use, it is sufficient to set the HandleView by calling FlexibleViewHolder.setDragHandleView(View).
        Returns:
        true if active, false otherwise
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        setHandleDragEnabled(boolean)

      • setHandleDragEnabled

        public final FlexibleAdapter<T> setHandleDragEnabled(boolean handleDragEnabled)
        Enables / Disables the drag of the item with a handle view. Requires the Adapter being attached to the RecyclerView.

        Default value is false.

        Parameters:
        handleDragEnabled - true to activate, false otherwise
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1

      • isSwipeEnabled

        public final boolean isSwipeEnabled()
        Returns whether ItemTouchHelper should start a swipe operation if a pointer is swiped over the View.

        Default value is false.

        Returns:
        true if ItemTouchHelper should start swiping an item when user swipes a pointer over the View, false otherwise. Default value is false.
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1
        See Also:
        setSwipeEnabled(boolean)

      • setSwipeEnabled

        public final FlexibleAdapter<T> setSwipeEnabled(boolean swipeEnabled)
        Enables full the swipe of the items.

        Note:

        • Requires the Adapter being attached to the RecyclerView.
        • Must override getFrontView and at least a rear View: getRearLeftView and/or getRearRightView in the FlexibleViewHolder.
        Default value is false.
        Parameters:
        swipeEnabled - true to activate, false otherwise
        Returns:
        this Adapter, so the call can be chained
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1

      • moveItem

        public void moveItem(int fromPosition,
                     int toPosition)
        Moves the item placed at position fromPosition to the position toPosition.
        - Selection of moved element is preserved.
        - If item is an expandable, it is collapsed and then expanded at the new position.
        Parameters:
        fromPosition - previous position of the item
        toPosition - new position of the item
        Since:
        5.0.0-b7
        See Also:
        moveItem(int, int, Object)

      • moveItem

        public void moveItem(int fromPosition,
                     int toPosition,
                     @Nullable
                     java.lang.Object payload)
        Moves the item placed at position fromPosition to the position toPosition.
        - Selection of moved element is preserved.
        - If item is an expandable, it is collapsed and then expanded at the new position.
        Parameters:
        fromPosition - previous position of the item
        toPosition - new position of the item
        payload - allows to update the content of the item just moved
        Since:
        5.0.0-b7

      • swapItems

        public void swapItems(java.util.List<T> list,
                      int fromPosition,
                      int toPosition)
        Swaps the elements of list at indices fromPosition and toPosition and notify the change.

        Selection of swiped elements is automatically updated.

        Parameters:
        fromPosition - previous position of the item.
        toPosition - new position of the item.
        Since:
        5.0.0-b7

      • onActionStateChanged

        public void onActionStateChanged(androidx.recyclerview.widget.RecyclerView.ViewHolder viewHolder,
                                 int actionState)
        Called when the ItemTouchHelper first registers an item as being moved or swiped or when has been released.

        Override this method to receive touch events with its state.

        Specified by:
        onActionStateChanged in interface ItemTouchHelperCallback.AdapterCallback
        Parameters:
        viewHolder - the viewHolder touched
        actionState - one of ItemTouchHelper.ACTION_STATE_SWIPE or ItemTouchHelper.ACTION_STATE_DRAG or ItemTouchHelper.ACTION_STATE_IDLE.
        Since:
        5.0.0-b7

      • shouldMove

                          int toPosition)
        Evaluate if positions are compatible for swapping.
        Specified by:
        shouldMove in interface ItemTouchHelperCallback.AdapterCallback
        Parameters:
        fromPosition - the start position of the moving item
        toPosition - the potential target position of the moving item
        Returns:
        true if the from-item is allowed to swap with the to-item
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1

      • onItemMove

        @CallSuper
public boolean onItemMove(int fromPosition,
                                      int toPosition)
        Called when an item has been dragged far enough to trigger a move. This is called every time an item is shifted, and not at the end of a "drop" event.

        Implementations should call RecyclerView.Adapter.notifyItemMoved(int, int) after adjusting the underlying data to reflect this move.

        Specified by:
        onItemMove in interface ItemTouchHelperCallback.AdapterCallback
        Parameters:
        fromPosition - the start position of the moved item
        toPosition - the resolved position of the moved item
        Returns:
        true if the from-item has been swapped with the to-item
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1

      • onItemSwiped

        @CallSuper
public void onItemSwiped(int position,
                                     int direction)
        Called when an item has been dismissed by a swipe.

        Implementations should decide to call or not RecyclerView.Adapter.notifyItemRemoved(int) after adjusting the underlying data to reflect this removal.

        Specified by:
        onItemSwiped in interface ItemTouchHelperCallback.AdapterCallback
        Parameters:
        position - the position of the item dismissed
        direction - the direction to which the ViewHolder is swiped
        Since:
        5.0.0-b1

      • hasSubItemsSelected

                                    java.util.List<T> subItems)

        Parameters:
        startPosition - helps to improve performance, so we can avoid a new search for position
        subItems - the list of sub items to check

      • invalidateItemDecorations

        public final void invalidateItemDecorations(long delay)
        Helper method to post invalidate the item decorations after the provided delay.

        The delay will give time to the LayoutManagers to complete the layout of the child views.

        Tip: A delay of 100ms should be enough, anyway it can be customized.
        Parameters:
        delay - delay to invalidate the decorations
